Organize your proof with bullets like '-', '+', and '*' instead of braces ({, }). Shift to their double symbols like '--' and '++', when necessary.
Effectively use given premises, follow the syntax and structure demonstrated in the examples provided.

Example 1:

Hypotheses:

vec_zero = vec_plus u v -> u = vec_zero /\ v = vec_zero

Inductive nat : Set := O : nat | S : nat -> nat Arguments S _%nat_scope
vec_plus = fun v w : vec nat n => vec_set_pos (fun p : pos n => vec_pos v p + vec_pos w p) : vec nat n -> vec nat n -> vec nat n

vec_plus_assoc : forall u v w : vec nat n, vec_plus u (vec_plus v w) = vec_plus (vec_plus u v) w
vec_zero_spec : forall p : pos n, vec_pos vec_zero p = 0
vec_plus_comm : forall v w : vec nat n, vec_plus v w = vec_plus w v
VectorSpec.nth_map2 : forall (f : ?A -> ?B -> ?C) (n0 : nat) (v0 : vec ?A n0) (w : vec ?B n0) (p1 p2 p3 : pos n0), p1 = p2 -> p2 = p3 -> VectorDef.nth (VectorDef.map2 f v0 w) p1 = f (VectorDef.nth v0 p2) (VectorDef.nth w p3) where ?A : [n : nat u : vec nat n v : vec nat n |- Type] ?B : [n : nat u : vec nat n v : vec nat n |- Type] ?C : [n : nat u : vec nat n v : vec nat n |- Type]
